content.description: Perhaps one of the top 3 traverses on Avery Drive. We nicknamed this problem 'Thanks for the pump' for its natural ability to give you a flash pump if you aren't careful. Some of the coolest moves and holds.This traverse is 20 moves one way and a pumpy 40 move lap! A fairly new traverse so the holds are sharp and grippy. The Crux is a thin section with micro edges for foot holds.
content.protection: A pad helps for the rocks in the crux section.
content.location: Coming down into The Lair you will see the Puzzle Traverse. It is located just down the trail to the left.

content.description: Start at the two horizontal crimps above your head, move up the crimps, use jug and dirty but good ledge to top out or match at the block and jump down.
content.location: From parking lot walk to the rec center along the road, look for stairs leading down to the area by The Lair, it will be on your left at the very end of the wall on your left just before the arete

content.description: The Puzzle is made up of a whole wall of horizontal holds. Though it may look easy, this traverse will surprise you. Most of the holds are slopers and the feet are pretty thin. A lap of this traverse brings a V5.
content.protection: A pad isn't necessary for this traverse.
content.location: The key indicator that you have arrived in The Lair. Once you get to the end of the overhanging rock it will be right in front of you.

content.description: A classic and quality Arete problem. It does have anchors at the top but have been there for some time. I saw a group using them in August 2019 but give them a check yourself for your own peace of mind. This can be bouldered out and it's real spicy.
content.protection: A couple pads and spotters if you choose to not TR it.
content.location: Headed down the hallway from the main stairs this will be before you get to The Lair on the right. Look for it when you have to go around a rock that we call the 'slice of pie'

content.description: Start on matched crimps below the corner overhang. Climb the arete using both sides. Climb up to the last good ledge turn the corner to top out or down climb the face to get in a bit more climbing and keep your shoes clean.
content.location: Locate Masters Arete (with large triangle shape rock at the base - on the Autobahn) then proceed north to the 20’ wall. Walk left slightly down hill along the wall. Honey Badger overhang is at the end (corner) of the wall.

content.description: Climbs the obvious Arete on the warm up buttress. Starts on the left side on eye level flat edges and goes to the right up the arete. Fun moves on this one with a great top out.
content.protection: A pad should be just fine.
content.location: The proud Arete of the warm up buttress.

content.description: This traverse is a V3 one way, V5 lap. The Crux is right in the middle of the traverse when you have to pull a sloper crimp (the cyclops eye)
content.location: Walking past Puzzle Traverse, stay on the trail and you will walk right to it. It will be on the left next to a hallway leading to a great warm up area and the boulder problems, Rec Center and Short but Stout.

content.description: Super quality for the grade. Starts on a flat edge and small side pull. Slab your way up and slightly left through a series of pockets and edges to a spicy top out! The movement on this one is just amazing. A must do if you are visiting the park especially with 'Short but Stout' right behind it.
content.protection: A couple pads and a spotter wouldn't hurt.
content.location: Go to the heart of The Lair and it is on the right side of the warm up buttress.

content.description: Jays Lair comes from Jay Kirby. A local who has put up many classic problems on Avery. Some include:Tin Man [V4]Iron Man [V5]Yellow traverse [V3+ stand, V4 sit, V5 lap]Thug Traverse [V5]Rec Center [V5]
